1.text:
For me, the biggest problem facing the planet
is energy. How are we going to find enough

7.text:
energy without warming up the planet so much
that we destroy our environment?

25.text:
I was a research student here in the 1970s
and looking around the quad is much the same

30.text:
now as it was then. No big changes, the trees
have grown up.

34.text:
There's one thing that has changed and that's
the air we breathe. The air here in Newcastle

39.text:
has changed. It contains far more carbon dioxide
now than it did then. That's down to the way

46.text:
we use fossil fuels to make energy.
The one source of energy that is abundant

55.text:
across the developed and the developing world
is the sun's energy. We need to learn how

61.text:
to use more of the sun's energy to generate
both our electricity and our fuels.

66.text:
We use the sun's energy already to generate
some of our electricity. But I look at plants

72.text:
and think that if the plants can convert the
sun's energy to fuels to be stored as starch,

78.text:
why can't we do that too?
If we look back at the Royal Society journals,

82.text:
we find James Barber in 2007 describe in intimate
detail how plants use the sun's energy to

89.text:
generate oxygen from water. He also shows
how we might learn from the plant's mechanisms

96.text:
how to do our own artificial version of photosynthesis
in a lab.

102.text:
I take inspiration from Barber's work and
from his own mentor George Porter, the Nobel

108.text:
Prize-winning photochemist who set about measuring
the first steps of photosynthesis with the

113.text:
aid of laser flashes lasting a millionth of
a millionth of a second.

118.text:
Back in 1978 Porter wrote in the Royal Society
journals on the possibility of using the principles

126.text:
of using the natural photosynthesis to teach
us how to do artificial photosynthesis.

132.text:
I'm here to catch up with Dr Libby Gibson.
Libby was a former research student, but she's

136.text:
now moved to Newcastle to set up her own lab
to do work on this subject.

142.text:
"We're using chemistry to convert sunlight
into electricity. All of our work is based

148.text:
on dye-sensitised solar cells. These are different
from the conventional crystallised silicon

153.text:
panels that you may be used to seeing on rooftops."
"So what goes on with these dye-sensitised cells."

161.text:
have the silicon semi-conductor doing the
light absorption and transporting the charge

165.text:
- doing all of the work - you need really
pure material and large quantities. We separate

172.text:
all the processes out: the dye absorbs
the light, and the semi-conductor and an electrolyte

177.text:
solution do the charge transport. This means
that we can use less amounts of materials

184.text:
and less pure materials to do our work."
"But it sounds much more complicated than

189.text:
the silicon with all these different components."
"Yes. That's what makes the field interesting

197.text:
that you can have many different components
and tune each to have different properties

202.text:
to improve the efficiency, but also to suit
different applications. We've opened up new

207.text:
opportunities for different applications of
solar energy."

211.text:
"What can you do with the solar energy that
you couldn't do with the silicon panel that

216.text:
I have on my roof?"
"The problem with silicon panels is that you

220.text:
need direct sunlight. They work best on a
sunny day at lunchtime, but light isn't direct.

227.text:
You can see in a room it's diffuse and scattered
off objects. By using semi-conductors of crystals

233.text:
at the nanoscale, we can collect
light in all different orientations, in all

240.text:
different types of light conditions, even
indoors if we want to. In my lab we are working

246.text:
on tandem dye-sensitised solar cells. This takes
advantage of the fact that we've got dyes

253.text:
in our devices that are absorbing light. We
can make different-coloured dyes to absorb

258.text:
different parts of sunlight, so we can capture
the full spectrum in one device. You can't

265.text:
do this with a semi-conductor like silicon.
The other thing that we're doing is avoiding

271.text:
using precious or rare metals, because if
we want to generate power on a global scale,

276.text:
we don't want to be limited by the materials
that we're using. How did you get interested

281.text:
in solar energy?"
"Well, I've been doing photochemistry for

285.text:
ages and I was always fascinated by reactions
that you could start with light but that you

292.text:
couldn't do at all without light. As it became
obvious that we really have our work cut out

299.text:
about solar energy, I looked to the natural
systems and there were fantastic advances

304.text:
in the natural systems, and that's what really
inspired me to get going on solar energy.

309.text:
It also reminds me about the greenhouse effect.
It's around the same time that Arrhenius,

314.text:
a Swedish chemist, got his ideas about the
greenhouse effect, carbon dioxide, and the

321.text:
climate (1896), but the actual discovery of
the greenhouse effect went back even further

327.text:
to a paper in Philosophical Transactions published
by John Tyndall in 1861. Then you go back

334.text:
further still to the giants who first investigated
light - Newton, particularly.

342.text:
Another of the pioneers of the Royal Society was John Evelyn,
he was worried that we were destroying all

347.text:
our forests and that we needed alternative
fuel. The worry about fuels goes back a long way too."

353.text: "The chemistry community is now working really

357.text:
hard to try and use photochemistry to make
fuel. There's an enormous effort in this area.

365.text:
We know that the science works and we can
get there. What's really important and is

370.text:
really encouraging, is that industry is so
keen to take on this new technology. This

375.text:
is clear from the interest of many large international
companies in the pilot dye-sensitised solar

382.text:
cell plant that they have in Swansea, UK."
"At the heart of the concept of the building

387.text:
as a power station is the ability to print
and coat different materials. The way that

392.text:
we're able to print and coat those materials
gives them different properties - if you treat

396.text:
them one way you can make a solar cell, if
you treat them another way you can make a

401.text:
battery. The concepts of printing and coating
allow you to produce very cheap, low energy

408.text:
materials which can be used for generating,
storing and releasing energy."

413.text:
"I'm optimistic that we can find the solutions
to producing power on a global scale and without

418.text:
being limited by the availability of the materials
that we use. What about you?"

423.text:
"Well I think it's incredibly important that
we put maximum effort into this. We need lots

430.text:
of scientific effort to do it. We've got to
really push hard on solar fuels and solar

436.text:
electricity if we're going to have enough
renewable energy."
